Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Two-Stage Processing Approach to Shape-Switching Liquid-Crystalline Elastomers for Biomedical Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant will pioneer a novel approach towards manufacturing tailored liquid-crystalline elastomers (LCEs), while uncovering fundamental structure-programming-performance relationships within these materials. LCEs are a class of smart and active polymers that can reversibly and repeatedly change their shape in response to a stimulus such as heat. Shape-changing polymers have tremendous potential to produce a variety of actuator applications such as artificial muscles or minimally invasive biomedical devices; however, LCEs have yet to be successfully developed into these applications because of processing limitations. If successful, the proposed two-stage reaction will overcome current chemistry and manufacturing barriers by providing explicit control over polymer structure and domain alignment. This approach will significantly increase the size scale at which LCEs can be produced, while providing a faster and more repeatable reaction mechanism compared to traditional approaches. As a result, this research will uncover the key relationships to enable the design and development of LCEs for a range of applications. An annual summer workshop series is planned to motivate and attract high school students to pursue careers in engineering.

One of the major challenges for LCEs to perform this shape-switching behavior is that the polymeric chains must be aligned to form a liquid-crystalline domain. A two-stage chemical reaction will be developed using functionalized monomers to overcome the chemistry barrier often associated with the synthesis of these materials. The first stage of the reaction will create a lightly crosslinked liquid-crystal polymer. The influence of both initial crosslinks and temperature on maximum achievable stretch will be investigated in order to optimize the amount of chain alignment. The second stage of the reaction will use ultraviolet light to further crosslink the material and keep the polymer chains in their aligned orientation. The influence of photo-crosslinks will be investigated for the effectiveness of retaining the aligned shape. Ultimately, crosslinking and stretching conditions will be linked to shape-switching performance and work capacity of the LCE materials. The proposed approach utilizes two independent reactions allowing for the initial synthesis and programming of the aligned material to occur at two distinct time points, offering the ability for stretching and crosslinking to occur two separate steps. This feature will not only help promote research collaborations but would enable manufacturing flexibility once the process is fully realized.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Denver-Downtown Campus
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project entitled “A Two-Stage Processing Approach to Shape-Switching Liquid-Crystalline Elastomers for Biomedical Applications” has been successfully completed. During this award, the PI investigated a novel method to produce liquid-crystal elastomers (LCEs) – a unique class of materials known for their extraordinary properties but was traditionally challenging to manufacture. The method involved thiol-acrylate chemistries, which allowed these materials to be synthesized with commercially available materials. Furthermore, the selected chemistry allowed for two reactions used to synthesize these materials to occur independently and in bulk. Overall, this helped overcome traditional barriers for scientists and engineers to explore these materials. 


The PI published over 15 studies during this award, demonstrating how this methodology could create and investigate LCEs. Specifically, the PI showed that these materials could be programmed to display reversible shape-memory behavior. In other words, the material could actuate like an artificial muscle when heated and cooled. In addition, this research served as a platform to integrate these materials into advanced manufacturing techniques such as 3D-printing. In one study, the LCE materials were combined with 3D-printed structures with electrically conductive inks to create soft robots and morphing structures. The chemistry was adapted to 3D-print biomedical devices in two studies, such as spinal fusion cages, using two types of techniques: direct-ink writing and digital light processing. 


This research was used to help first demonstrate the existence of a predicted state of LCEs, known as the negative order parameter. The two independent reactions of the processing method allowed LCE spherical shells to be manufactured, expanded, and locked into a negative order state. This research was also the first to demonstrate the rate-dependent and energy-absorbing nature of these materials, which have since been proposed for protective devices such as helmets.


The research also helped produced 1 issued patent and 5 PhD students under the PI’s supervision. 

 


Last Modified: 11/18/2020
Modified by: Christopher Yakacki

Image

    Nicholas A. Traugutt, Devesh Mistry, Chaoqian Luo, Kai Yu, Qi Ge, and Christopher M. Yakacki
    Christopher Yakacki
    LCE Spinal Cage
